title: Is being unwilling to learn new technologies a sign of senility? - Quora

response.answer_text: There’s a difference between unwilling and unable. I would suggest that an unwillingness to learn new technologies is not in any way a sign of senility. Ever had a “hot new” device/gadget/app that you refused to use? If you’re unwilling to use it—or to learn how to use it—then you’re simply not interested. Your conscious decision not to learn the new technology doesn’t mean that you’re somehow less capable than others who choose to embrace it. Ever had something you felt you were unable to learn? Perhaps something you tried to learn but discovered that it didn’t come so easily? In such cases, you must eventually decide whether or not the activity is worth your continued time and effort. If you’re truly unable to learn something, then it could be a sign of various physical or mental limitations, only one of which is senility. However, there are also so many people who say things like, “Oh, I can’t do math,” as they dismiss a numerical question that could be answered with mathematical skills. Is it true that they can’t do it, or are they simply uninterested in making the investment necessary to learn how? The science of neuroplasticity has shown us that lifelong learning is possible for everyone, including the oldest among us. I cringe when a TV show portrays an older adult with a cell phone as a bumbling idiot, or when a grandchild mocks grandma’s attempt to send a personal text using emojis, or when a 30-something-year-old hiring manager presupposes that a 60-something-year-old applicant is “too old” to master the technology requirements of a job. In looking for a way to identify signs of senility, I wouldn’t necessarily point to the older adult’s adoption of or interest in new technology. A better gauge might involve comparing cognitive performance in tasks the person has always done—then and now—to find out whether aging has led to diminished capacity in things familiar to the individual.

Not in my experience. The problem with new technologies for those of us who can function without them, is that they are usually really expensive. My parents would never have paid several hundred if not thousands of dollars for a phone ever. I don’t intend to either. I am currently using a cellphone I purchased in 2004, I have had other cellphones in the interim, but they have broken or not made properly to begin with. My old cellphone will be going obsolete soon and I will be without one, I just don’t care. No senility involved. Ditto for laptops and computers. I am sick of doling out money for technology that is going to be obsolete in a year or less. Of course a person could be suffering from senility and also be uninterested in new technologies. It just isn’t necessarily true.
